[
    "The atmosphere of Jupiter is approximately 76% hydrogen and 24% helium by mass.",
    "By volume, Jupiter's upper atmosphere is about 90% hydrogen and 10% helium.",
    "Jupiter's atmosphere contains trace amounts of elemental carbon, oxygen, sulfur, and neon.",
    "Jupiter's atmosphere contains ammonia, water vapour, phosphine, hydrogen sulfide, and hydrocarbons such as methane, ethane and benzene.",
    "Jupiter's outermost atmospheric layer contains crystals of frozen ammonia.",
    "Jupiter's interior composition is roughly 71% hydrogen, 24% helium, and 5% other elements by mass.",
    "Neon in Jupiter's upper atmosphere consists of about 20 parts per million by mass, which is about a tenth as abundant as in the Sun.",
    "Jupiter's helium abundance is about 80% that of the Sun due to precipitation of helium-rich droplets deep in the planet's interior.",
    "Saturn is thought by spectroscopy to be similar in composition to Jupiter.",
    "Uranus and Neptune have relatively less hydrogen and helium and relatively more oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur compared to Jupiter and Saturn.",
    "Uranus and Neptune are referred to as ice giants because during their formation heavier volatile elements are thought to have been incorporated into them as ice.",
    "Gas giants consist mostly of hydrogen and helium.",
    "The Solar System's gas giants, Jupiter and Saturn, have heavier elements making up between 3 and 13 percent of their mass.",
    "Gas giants are thought to consist of an outer layer of molecular hydrogen, surrounding a layer of liquid metallic hydrogen, with a probable molten core with a rocky composition.",
    "The outermost portion of Jupiter and Saturn's hydrogen atmosphere has many layers of visible clouds that are mostly composed of water and ammonia.",
    "The layer of metallic hydrogen in gas giants is referred to as 'metallic' because very high pressure turns hydrogen into an electrical conductor.",
    "The core of gas giants is thought to consist of heavier elements at temperatures around 20,000 K, and their properties are poorly understood.",
    "The New Frontiers program includes objectives to determine Jupiter's core mass and size and to characterize its gravitational and magnetic fields and internal convection.",
    "The New Frontiers program includes objectives to measure the Jovian atmospheric composition, temperature profile, wind velocity profile, and cloud opacity to greater depths than achieved by the Galileo entry probe, with a goal of reaching 100 bar at multiple latitudes.",
    "The New Frontiers program includes objectives to investigate and characterize the three-dimensional structure of Jupiter's polar magnetosphere.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere is the cavity created in the solar wind by Jupiter's magnetic field.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere extends up to seven million kilometers in the Sun's direction and almost to the orbit of Saturn in the opposite direction.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere is the largest and most powerful planetary magnetosphere in the Solar System and, by volume, the largest known continuous structure in the Solar System after the heliosphere.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere is wider and flatter than Earth's magnetosphere and is stronger by an order of magnitude.",
    "Jupiter's magnetic moment is roughly 18,000 times larger than Earth's magnetic moment.",
    "The existence of Jupiter's magnetic field was first inferred from observations of radio emissions at the end of the 1950s and was directly observed by the Pioneer 10 spacecraft in 1973.",
    "Jupiter's internal magnetic field is generated by electrical currents in the planet's outer core, which is theorized to be composed of liquid metallic hydrogen.",
    "Volcanic eruptions on Jupiter's moon Io eject large amounts of sulfur dioxide gas into space, forming a large torus around the planet.",
    "Jupiter's magnetic field forces the Io torus to rotate with the same angular velocity and direction as the planet.",
    "The Io torus loads Jupiter's magnetic field with plasma, stretching it into a pancake-like structure called a magnetodisk.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere is primarily shaped by Io's plasma and Jupiter's rotation rather than by the solar wind.",
    "Strong currents in Jupiter's magnetosphere generate permanent aurorae around the planet's poles and intense variable radio emissions.",
    "Jupiter's aurorae have been observed in infrared, visible, ultraviolet and soft X-rays.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere traps and accelerates particles, producing intense radiation belts thousands of times stronger than Earth's Van Allen belts.",
    "Those energetic particles interact with the surfaces of Jupiter's largest moons and affect their chemical and physical properties.",
    "Radiation belts around Jupiter present a significant hazard for spacecraft and potentially for human space travellers.",
    "Jupiter's atmosphere is primarily composed of molecular hydrogen and helium, with smaller amounts of water, methane, hydrogen sulfide, and ammonia.",
    "Jupiter's atmosphere extends to a depth of approximately 3,000 kilometres below the cloud layers.",
    "Jupiter's magnetic field has a dipole moment of 4.170 gauss (0.4170 mT) tilted at an angle of 10.31° to the pole of rotation.",
    "Jupiter's surface magnetic field strength varies from 2 gauss (0.20 mT) up to 20 gauss (2.0 mT).",
    "Jupiter's magnetic field is thought to be generated by eddy currents within the fluid metallic hydrogen core.",
    "At about 75 Jupiter radii from the planet, interaction of the magnetosphere with the solar wind generates a bow shock.",
    "Surrounding Jupiter's magnetosphere is a magnetopause located at the inner edge of a magnetosheath between it and the bow shock.",
    "The solar wind elongates Jupiter's magnetosphere on the lee side and can extend it outward nearly to Saturn's orbit.",
    "Jupiter's four largest moons all orbit within the planet's magnetosphere, which protects them from the solar wind.",
    "The Io volcanoes emit sulfur dioxide that forms a gas torus along Io's orbit, which becomes ionized in Jupiter's magnetosphere producing sulfur and oxygen ions.",
    "Sulfur and oxygen ions together with hydrogen ions from Jupiter's atmosphere form a plasma sheet in Jupiter's equatorial plane.",
    "The plasma in Jupiter's equatorial plasma sheet co-rotates with the planet, deforming the dipole magnetic field into a magnetodisk.",
    "Electrons within the plasma sheet generate a strong radio signature with short bursts in the range of 0.6–30 MHz that are detectable from Earth with consumer-grade shortwave radio receivers.",
    "As Io moves through the torus, the interaction generates Alfvén waves that carry ionized matter into Jupiter's polar regions and produce radio waves via a cyclotron maser mechanism.",
    "When Earth intersects the cone-shaped surface along which radio energy is transmitted from Jupiter, the radio emissions from Jupiter can exceed the radio output of the Sun.",
    "The Juno spacecraft has objectives to determine the oxygen-to-hydrogen ratio (to measure water abundance) and to obtain a better estimate of Jupiter's core mass.",
    "Juno's objectives include precisely mapping Jupiter's gravitational field to assess mass distribution and dynamics in the interior and precisely mapping Jupiter's magnetic field to assess its origin and the depth at which it is created.",
    "Juno aims to map variation in atmospheric composition, temperature, structure, cloud opacity and dynamics to pressures far greater than 100 bar at all latitudes.",
    "Juno aims to characterize and explore the three-dimensional structure of Jupiter's polar magnetosphere and auroras.",
    "Juno aims to measure frame-dragging (Lense–Thirring precession) caused by Jupiter's angular momentum and possibly test general relativity effects connected with Jovian rotation.",
    "Storms on Jupiter are similar to thunderstorms on Earth and appear as bright clumpy clouds about 1000 km in size.",
    "Jovian storms are short-lived phenomena with the strongest lasting several months and the average lifetime being 3–4 days.",
    "Jovian storms are believed to be due mainly to moist convection within Jupiter's troposphere and are tall convective columns (plumes).",
    "A typical vertical extent of Jovian storms is about 100 km, and they can extend from a pressure level of about 5–7 bar up to about 0.2–0.5 bar.",
    "Storms on Jupiter are always associated with lightning.",
    "Galileo and Cassini imaging revealed regular light flashes in Jovian belts and near westward jets, particularly at latitudes 51°N, 56°S and 14°S.",
    "On Jupiter, lightning strikes are on average a few times more powerful than those on Earth but are less frequent.",
    "A few lightning flashes have been detected in Jupiter's polar regions, making Jupiter the second known planet after Earth to exhibit polar lightning.",
    "A Microwave Radiometer on Juno detected many more Jovian lightning flashes in 2018.",
    "Every 15–17 years Jupiter experiences especially powerful storms that appear at 23°N latitude where the strongest eastward jet can reach 150 m/s.",
    "The last such especially powerful storm event was observed in March–June 2007.",
    "Some powerful storms moved with speeds as high as 170 m/s, slightly faster than the jet itself.",
    "Jupiter's visible surface is divided into several bands parallel to the equator, consisting of lightly colored zones and relatively dark belts.",
    "The Equatorial Zone (EZ) extends between approximately 7°S and 7°N latitude.",
    "The North and South Equatorial belts (NEB and SEB) extend to about 18°N and 18°S, respectively.",
    "Ammonia concentration is higher in zones, producing denser ammonia ice clouds at higher altitudes and leading to lighter color in zones.",
    "In belts, clouds are thinner and located at lower altitudes, and the upper troposphere is warmer in belts than in zones.",
    "The specific chemicals that make Jovian zones and bands colorful are not known, but may include compounds of sulfur, phosphorus and carbon.",
    "Jovian bands are bounded by zonal atmospheric flows called jets, with eastward (prograde) jets found at transitions from zones to belts and westward (retrograde) jets at transitions from belts to zones.",
    "Jet speeds on Jupiter reach more than 100 m/s and correspond to ammonia clouds located in the pressure range 0.7–1 bar.",
    "Prograde jets on Jupiter are generally more powerful than retrograde jets.",
    "The jets extend thousands of kilometers into Jupiter's interior and extend parallel to the planet's axis of rotation rather than radially toward the center.",
    "The Galileo probe measured a jet's vertical profile finding winds decay over two to three scale heights above the clouds and remain constant down to at least 22 bar below the cloud level.",
    "Jupiter radiates more heat than it receives from the Sun; the ratio of emitted to absorbed thermal power is 1.67 ± 0.09.",
    "Jupiter's internal heat flux is 5.44 ± 0.43 W/m2 and its total emitted power is 335 ± 26 petawatts.",
    "Jupiter's excess heat is mainly primordial heat from its formation and may partly result from precipitation of helium into the core.",
    "Jupiter's small obliquity of about 3° means its poles receive much less solar radiation than its equator, yet tropospheric temperatures do not change appreciably from equator to poles.",
    "One proposed explanation for Jupiter's uniform tropospheric temperature is that its convective interior releases more heat near the poles than the equator, acting like a thermostat.",
    "Meridional circulation cells on Jupiter are large-scale atmospheric motions where gas rises at certain latitudes, travels meridionally, descends, and returns in closed cells.",
    "Visible cloud bands on Jupiter indicated upward motion in zones and downward motion in belts for the upper few bars, but deeper observations suggested the opposite in the deeper atmosphere.",
    "Juno's microwave measurements probe Jupiter's atmosphere down to about 240 bar and confirmed mid-latitude large circulation cells with upward motion in the belts and downward motion in the zones, extending from about 1 bar down to at least 240 bar.",
    "So far, eight meridional circulation cells have been identified at each of Jupiter's hemispheres along latitudes 20°–60° N and S.",
    "The mid-latitude meridional cells on Jupiter are driven by breaking of atmospheric waves, similar to Earth's Ferrel cells.",
    "On Earth the return flow in cells' lower branch is balanced by friction in the Ekman layer; on Jupiter the lower-branch balance is unknown, but magnetic drag is a possible mechanism.",
    "The Great Red Spot is a persistent anticyclonic storm located 22° south of Jupiter's equator.",
    "The Great Red Spot was first observed in 1831 and possibly as early as 1665.",
    "The Great Red Spot is visible through Earth-based telescopes with an aperture of 12 cm or larger.",
    "The Great Red Spot rotates counterclockwise with a period of about six days.",
    "The maximum altitude of the Great Red Spot is about 8 kilometres above the surrounding cloud tops.",
    "The composition and source of the Great Red Spot's red colour remain uncertain, though photodissociated ammonia reacting with acetylene is a likely explanation.",
    "The Great Red Spot is larger than the Earth.",
    "Mathematical models suggest the Great Red Spot is stable and could be a permanent feature of Jupiter.",
    "The Great Red Spot has significantly decreased in size since its discovery.",
    "In the late 1800s the Great Red Spot was approximately 41,000 km across.",
    "As of 2015 the Great Red Spot measured approximately 16,500 by 10,940 kilometres and was decreasing in length by about 930 km per year.",
    "A Juno flyby in October 2021 measured the depth of the Great Red Spot at around 300–500 kilometres.",
    "Juno found several cyclone groups at Jupiter's poles: the northern group contains nine cyclones with a central one surrounded by eight others, and the southern group contains a central vortex surrounded by five large storms and one smaller one for a total of seven.",
    "In 2000 an atmospheric feature called Oval BA formed in Jupiter's southern hemisphere from the merger of smaller white ovals formed in 1939–1940; it increased in intensity and changed from white to red and was nicknamed 'Little Red Spot'.",
    "In April 2017 a 'Great Cold Spot' was discovered in Jupiter's thermosphere at its north pole that is 24,000 km across, 12,000 km wide, and about 200 °C cooler than surrounding material.",
    "The Great Cold Spot has maintained its general position in Jupiter's atmosphere for more than 15 years and may be a giant vortex similar to the Great Red Spot.",
    "The Great Cold Spot may be formed by interactions between charged particles generated from Io and Jupiter's strong magnetic field, resulting in redistribution of heat flow.",
    "A gas giant is a giant planet composed mainly of hydrogen and helium.",
    "Jupiter and Saturn are the gas giants of the Solar System.",
    "The term 'gas giant' was originally synonymous with 'giant planet', but in the 1990s Uranus and Neptune were recognized as a distinct class called ice giants composed mainly of heavier volatile substances.",
    "The placement of the Solar System's gas giants can be explained by the grand tack hypothesis.",
    "The defining differences between a very low-mass brown dwarf and a gas giant are debated, with some definitions based on formation and others on interior physics.",
    "Part of the debate about brown dwarfs versus gas giants concerns whether brown dwarfs must have experienced nuclear fusion at some point in their history."
] 
 
Claims:
[
    "Eddy currents and metallic hydrogen are central to understanding Jupiter's magnetic field, magnetosphere, and its interactions with moons, rings, and formation.",
    "Jupiter's magnetic field is generated by the dynamo effect in its metallic hydrogen layer.",
    "Under immense pressure (up to ~50 million bars), hydrogen transitions into a metallic state, becoming a highly conductive fluid.",
    "This conductive material, combined with Jupiter's rapid rotation (≈10 hours), creates a magnetohydrodynamic dynamo, generating a strong magnetic field (~14 Gauss at the surface, ~100,000 Gauss at the core).",
    "The motion of metallic hydrogen in the fluid core induces eddy currents (circular electric currents) that reinforce the magnetic field.",
    "These currents are sustained by convection and differential rotation in the metallic hydrogen layer.",
    "Jupiter's pronounced oblateness (flattened poles and bulging equator) is primarily due to its rapid rotation (~10 hours), not directly from the magnetic field.",
    "The magnetic field and internal convection in the metallic hydrogen layer contribute to the planet's internal structure and energy distribution, indirectly influencing its shape.",
    "The metallic hydrogen layer is thought to be in convection-driven turbulence, which transports heat from the core to the outer layers.",
    "This convection may also drive atmospheric phenomena (e.g., storms, auroras) and affect the planet's magnetic field geometry.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere is the largest in the solar system, extending millions of kilometers.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere is shaped by the magnetic field and interactions with the solar wind.",
    "The magnetic field is dominated by the equatorial field, which is amplified by the planet's rotation and metallic hydrogen dynamics.",
    "Io, the most volcanically active body in the solar system, continuously ejects plasma into space, forming a plasma torus around Jupiter.",
    "The Io plasma torus interacts with the magnetosphere, creating a current sheet that modulates the magnetic field and drives auroral activity.",
    "Jupiter's magnetic field influences its moons via induced magnetospheres (e.g., Ganymede, which has its own magnetic field) and charged particle radiation.",
    "The magnetosphere traps charged particles, creating intense radiation belts that affect the moons' surfaces and atmospheres.",
    "Jupiter’s rings are faint and composed primarily of dust and debris from collisions between small moons and meteoroids.",
    "Jupiter’s rings are not directly related to metallic hydrogen but may be influenced by the magnetosphere’s charged particles and the planet’s gravitational field.",
    "Jupiter’s formation involved accretion of gas and ice, with metallic hydrogen forming in the deep interior due to extreme pressure.",
    "The differentiation of elements (e.g., heavy elements sinking toward the core) contributed to the planet’s internal structure, including the metallic hydrogen layer.",
    "The differentiation process likely influenced the magnetic field generation and the planet’s oblateness.",
    "The conductivity of metallic hydrogen is critical for sustaining the magnetic field and eddy currents.",
    "Without this conductive layer, Jupiter’s magnetic field would be significantly weaker.",
    "The magnetosphere interacts with moons like Io, Europa, and Ganymede, shaping their geology and atmospheres.",
    "Io’s volcanic activity fuels the plasma torus, which in turn affects Jupiter’s magnetic field.",
    "The magnetic field guides charged particles to Jupiter’s poles, creating intense auroras.",
    "Jupiter’s auroras are linked to the planet’s internal dynamics and interactions with the solar wind.",
    "Eddy currents in Jupiter’s metallic hydrogen layer are the primary driver of its magnetic field, which in turn shapes the magnetosphere, influences moon interactions, and affects the planet’s oblateness and atmospheric phenomena.",
    "While the rings are unrelated to metallic hydrogen, the magnetosphere’s role in shaping the moons and rings is profound.",
    "Jupiter’s formation and internal dynamics, including metallic hydrogen, are foundational to understanding its magnetic and geophysical characteristics."
]

metric_data.name: Hallucination
metric_data.reason: The score is 0.00 because every claim in the actual output matches the provided context (dynamo in metallic hydrogen, magnetosphere/Io/aurorae details, oblateness from rapid rotation, ring dust origin, metallic hydrogen role in formation) and there are no contradictions.

metric_data.name: Answer Relevancy
metric_data.reason: The score is 0.93 because most of the description was accurate — correct cloud layering (ammonia, ammonium hydrosulfide, water), mushball formation as a proposed mechanism, helium rain and a layered interior — but two overstated causal links lowered the score. Linking mushballs to auroral activity is incorrect (aurora are driven by magnetospheric particle precipitation); mushballs may affect charge separation and thus could play a role in lightning, but that remains speculative. Claiming helium rain combined with metallic‑hydrogen conductivity directly sustains storms like the Great Red Spot is unsubstantiated — large storms are primarily driven by fluid dynamics and internal heat; helium rain alters composition and heat transport but is not a proven direct driver of storm maintenance. Fixing those two overstatements would make the output fully relevant.

metric_data.name: Hallucination
metric_data.reason: The score is 0.00 because the actual output's claims (helium rain from phase separation, mushballs transporting ammonia and water, a diffuse/fuzzy core and metallic hydrogen layer influencing dynamics, deep convection driving storms, cloud-pressure levels and lightning origins, and the GRS depth ≈300 km) are all directly supported by the provided context and there are no contradictions.

metric_data.name: Answer Relevancy
metric_data.reason: The score is 0.94 because the response was largely on-topic and discussed Jupiter’s composition, but it lost points for including general/implication statements that did not provide the requested quantitative H/He mass fractions or specific heavy-element distribution between atmosphere and interior.

Truths (limit=None):
[
    "Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun, the largest in the Solar System, and is classified as a gas giant.",
    "The NASA spacecraft Juno, launched on August 5, 2011, entered a polar orbit of Jupiter on July 5, 2016.",
    "Juno's scientific results include providing the first views of Jupiter's north pole and information that revised theories about Jovian lightning.",
    "Juno's discoveries challenge existing theories about Jupiter's formation, finding its magnetosphere to be uneven and its interior not evenly mixed.",
    "Data from Juno has led to the theory that Jupiter has a "fuzzy" core of rock and metallic hydrogen, not a solid one as previously thought.",
    "Juno found that Jupiter's red and white atmospheric bands extend hundreds of kilometers into the planet's atmosphere.",
    "In 2021, analysis of dust impacts on Juno indicated that interplanetary dust causing the Zodiacal light comes from Mars.",
    "Juno's results show some of Jupiter's storms extend 100 kilometers below the cloud tops, with the Great Red Spot extending over 350 kilometers deep.",
    "Using NASA's Deep Space Network, Juno scientists measured the depth of the Great Red Spot to be about 500 kilometers below the cloud tops.",
    "Jupiter is perpetually covered with clouds of ammonia crystals located in the tropopause layer, which is about 50 km deep.",
    "The planet's atmosphere is divided into lighter-hued zones and darker belts, with wind speeds of 100 metres per second being common in the zonal jet streams.",
    "Electrical discharges on Jupiter can be a thousand times more powerful than lightning on Earth.",
    "The Juno mission revealed "shallow lightning" originating from high-altitude ammonia-water clouds, which carry "mushballs" of water-ammonia slush.",
    "Upper-atmospheric lightning, known as "elves" or "sprites," has been observed in Jupiter's upper atmosphere.",
    "Jupiter's atmosphere is the largest in the Solar System and is primarily composed of molecular hydrogen and helium.",
    "The Galileo atmospheric probe directly observed Jupiter's atmosphere upon entry on December 7, 1995.",
    "Jupiter radiates more heat than it receives from the Sun, which is mainly primordial heat from its formation.",
    "Jupiter's magnetosphere is the largest and most powerful of any planetary magnetosphere in the Solar System.",
    "The planet's magnetic field is generated by electrical currents in its outer core, which is composed of liquid metallic hydrogen.",
    "Volcanic eruptions on Jupiter's moon Io eject sulfur dioxide gas, forming a large torus around the planet that interacts with the magnetosphere.",
    "The Great Red Spot is a persistent anticyclonic storm located 22° south of the equator, first observed in 1831.",
    "The Great Red Spot is larger than Earth but has significantly decreased in size since its discovery in the late 1800s.",
    "Juno missions discovered stable clusters of cyclones at both of Jupiter's poles.",
    "An atmospheric feature named Oval BA, nicknamed "Little Red Spot", formed in the southern hemisphere in 2000 from the merger of three smaller storms.",
    "In April 2017, a "Great Cold Spot" was discovered in Jupiter's thermosphere at its north pole, measuring 24,000 km across.",
    "Jupiter has at least 97 moons, and its four largest moons are Io, Europa, Ganymede, and Callisto.",
    "Ganymede, Jupiter's largest moon, is larger than the planet Mercury.",
    "Jupiter is surrounded by a faint system of planetary rings composed mainly of dust."
] 
 
Claims:
[
    "Jupiter's magnetic field is generated by the dynamo effect in its metallic hydrogen core.",
    "Jupiter's core is a 'fuzzy' core composed of metallic hydrogen and heavy elements (such as oxygen, silicon, and iron) mixed with rocky material.",
    "The core is surrounded by a layer of metallic hydrogen, which is a highly conductive fluid state of hydrogen under extreme pressure and temperature.",
    "The dynamo effect is a process where the motion of electrically conductive fluids, in this case metallic hydrogen, creates and sustains magnetic fields.",
    "Intense convection within the metallic hydrogen layer, driven by Jupiter's internal heat and gravitational forces, causes swirling currents of charged particles which generate the magnetic field.",
    "Heavy elements in Jupiter's core, like oxygen and iron, increase the electrical conductivity of the metallic hydrogen layer, enhancing the dynamo process.",
    "Jupiter's magnetic field forms a vast magnetosphere that interacts with the solar wind and the plasma torus generated by its moon Io's volcanic activity.",
    "Jupiter's magnetic field is about 20,000 times stronger than Earth's due to the immense size of its metallic hydrogen layer and its high conductivity.",
    "Unlike Earth's geodynamo which relies on molten iron, Jupiter's field is powered by the properties of metallic hydrogen under extreme conditions.",
    "NASA's Juno mission revealed that the diffuse, 'fuzzy' core structure plays a role in shaping the magnetic field's complexity.",
    "Jupiter is the most magnetically active planet in the solar system."
]

Truths (limit=None):
[
    "The Great Red Spot (GRS) is a persistent anticyclonic storm on Jupiter, located 22° south of the equator.",
    "The GRS rotates counterclockwise with a period of about six Earth days and is large enough to contain two or three Earth-sized planets.",
    "The GRS has been continuously observed since the 1870s, with possible earlier sightings by Giovanni Cassini in 1665.",
    "The GRS has significantly decreased in size; in the late 1800s it was 41,000 km across, while in 2015 it was measured at approximately 16,500 km by 10,940 km.",
    "The cause of the GRS's reddish color is unknown, though theories suggest it may be from complex organic molecules, red phosphorus, or sulfur compounds.",
    "A 2014 analysis of Cassini data suggests the red color is likely a product of chemicals being broken apart by solar ultraviolet irradiation in Jupiter's upper atmosphere.",
    "The GRS's visibility is linked to the South Equatorial Belt (SEB); when the belt is bright white, the spot tends to be dark, and vice versa.",
    "In 2000, three smaller white storms merged to form a single feature named Oval BA, also known as "Red Spot Jr." or the "Little Red Spot".",
    "Oval BA turned red in 2005-2006 and its wind speeds have reached 618 km/h, similar to the GRS.",
    "A separate storm, the South Tropical Little Red Spot ("the Baby Red Spot"), was shredded and consumed by the GRS in mid-2008.",
    "A "Great Cold Spot", 24,000 km across and 200°C cooler than its surroundings, was discovered in Jupiter's thermosphere at its north pole in 2017.",
    "Auroral colors are created by emissions from excited atomic oxygen and molecular nitrogen.",
    "At high altitudes, atomic oxygen emits red light; at lower altitudes, it emits green light, which is the most common auroral color.",
    "At the lowest altitudes, molecular nitrogen emissions create blue and purple light.",
    "The variation in auroral color with altitude is due to increasing particle density causing "collisional quenching," which prevents certain light emissions.",
    "Ultraviolet auroras, invisible to the human eye, have been observed on Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn.",
    "Io, one of Jupiter's moons, has a colorful surface due to materials like silicates, sulfur, and sulfur dioxide deposited by extensive volcanism.",
    "Radiation damage to sulfur in Io's polar regions is responsible for their red-brown color.",
    "Io has the least amount of water of any known body in the Solar System."
]

    "Sulfur-based chemicals and red phosphorus are suspected contributors to the GRS's color.",
    "Tholins, which are brown organic polymers formed by UV irradiation of simple molecules, are hypothesized to be transported into the GRS and contribute to its color.",
    "The GRS's color varies with temperature and its interactions with surrounding cloud layers.",
    "Higher temperatures in the central region of the GRS correlate with deeper red hues, while cooler areas appear lighter.",
    "The visibility of the GRS is linked to the South Equatorial Belt (SEB); when the belt is dark, the spot tends to be bright, and vice versa.",
    "Cassini data suggests that the red color may arise from simple chemicals being broken apart by UV radiation, which then combine to create the observed colors.",
    "The GRS occasionally fades or darkens, possibly due to changes in atmospheric dynamics or interactions with smaller storms.",
    "Similar phenomena, like the 'Little Red Spot' (Oval BA), suggest that color changes may result from localized chemical processes or shifts in atmospheric composition."
